questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the surface markers of T and B cells?
questions.solution:
T cells do not express CD10. CD10 is a marker of pre-B cell and germinal center B cells.

Given below is a list of cell surface markers and the cells they are expressed on:

  1. CD3: All T cells
  2. CD4: Helper T cells
  3. CD8: Cytotoxic T cells
  4. CD4, CD25: Regulatory T cells
  5. Ig, CD19, CD20, CD21: B Cells
  6. CD10: Pre-B Cells, germinal center B cells 
  7. CD40, MHC-II: Macrophages
  8. CD16, CD56: NK Cells 
  9. CD34: Hematopoietic stem cells 

Note : Pan T antigens are antigens found on all T cells and include CD2, CD3, CD5 and CD7.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the reticulate body of Chlamydia?
questions.solution:
The reticulate body of chlamydia is a growing and replicative form.

Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus that has the following features-

  • They are obligate intracellular organisms as they lack the enzymes for ATP synthesis, and are hence dependent entirely on the host cell. 
  • They can exist in two states.
    • The extracellular infective form is called the elementary body.
    • The intracellular non-infective form is called the reticulate body. These reticulate bodies are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the "inclusion body" which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by iodine or Giemsa stain. The cell of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leading to pleomorphism.
  • They are small bacteria about 0.2-0.3 microns in size and are hence filtrable through the pore size of standard bacterial filters.

questions.text: A male patient who presented with a lump in his right breast is diagnosed to have breast carcinoma. Which of the following is true regarding the given condition?

choices.text: The prognosis is worse than in females
Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type
Tamoxifen is not effective in treatment

questions.solution:
Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer seen in men.

Breast cancer in men accounts for less than 1% of all breast cancers. The peak incidence is between 60-70 years of age. Majority of the patients present with a hard mass in the breast. Important risk factors are:

  • BRCA2 mutation
  • Radiation exposure
  • Estrogen therapy
  • Testicular feminizing syndrome
  • Klinefelter syndrome

Diagnosis of male breast carcinoma is similar to females which involves a clinical examination, imaging, and tissue biopsy. Grading, treatment, and prognosis are the same as female breast cancer. The majority of male breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive and hence tamoxifen is used in the treatment.

questions.text: A young male patient presented with painless swelling of the scrotum. Examination revealed a firm, enlarged epididymis along with beading of the vas deferens. Testes were normal. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Send urine or semen for PCR

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a firm enlarged epididymis, beading of the vas deferens, and a normal testis on palpation indicate secondary tubercular epididymo-orchitis. The next best step is confirmation with polymerase chain reaction (PCR). 

Beading of the vas deferens is due to subepithelial tubercle formation and is specific to genital tuberculosis.

A scrotal USG will reveal an enlarged epididymis but does not have diagnostic value. Chest, kidney, and upper urinary tract imaging may reveal a primary focus.

Tuberculous epididymo-orchitis is usually secondary and resolves once the primary focus is treated. Hence, a course of anti-tubercular therapy must be completed even if there is no evidence of disease elsewhere.

If resolution does not occur within two months, epididymectomy or orchidectomy is advisable.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with pain in the right hip during ambulation for the past few months. There is no history of trauma. An X-ray done is shown below. Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation to confirm the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows flattening of the femoral head and degenerative changes associated with avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis of the femoral head. The most sensitive investigation to diagnose avascular necrosis is MRI.

MRI allows identification of avascular necrosis of the femoral head in earlier stages and also determines the exact stage and extent of the pathologic process.

The radiograph below shows the flattening of the femoral head in a patient with avascular necrosis.

The radiographic appearance of avascular necrosis of the femoral head may show the following changes:

  • Sclerosis of the femoral head
  • Flattening or loss of sphericity of femoral head
  • Crescent sign
  • In severe stages, it may show femoral head collapse and arthritic changes in the joint

The image given below shows osteonecrosis of the femoral head seen on an MRI.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with ascending muscle weakness for 2 days. On examination, the limb is flaccid.  Similar episodes were reported in the past, usually after prolonged exercise. What investigation should be done first?
questions.solution:
Flaccid ascending paralysis can be seen in case of hypokalemia. It causes periodic paralysis. Hence, serum potassium levels should be checked first.

Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis:

  • This is an autosomal dominant disorder with onset in adolescence.
  • Males are more often affected because of decreased penetrance in females.
  • Two types:
    • Type 1 with mutation in voltage sensitive, skeletal muscle calcium channel gene CALCL1A3.
    • Type 2 with mutation in voltage sensitive sodium channel gene SCN4A.
  • Attacks are often provoked by meals high in carbohydrates or sodium and may accompany rest following prolonged exercise.
  • Weakness usually affects proximal limb muscles more than distal.
  • Ocular and bulbar muscles are less likely to be affected.
  • Respiratory muscles are usually spared, but when they are involved, the condition may prove fatal.
  • Weakness may take as long as 24 hours to resolve.
  • Life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias related to hypokalemia may occur during attacks.
  • As a late complication, patients commonly develop severe, disabling proximal lower extremity weakness.

Diagnosis:

  • A low serum potassium level during an attack, excluding secondary causes, establishes the diagnosis.
  • In the midst of an attack of weakness, motor conduction studies may demonstrate reduced amplitudes, whereas EMG may show electrical silence in severely weak muscles.
  • In between attacks, the EMG and routine NCS are normal. However, a long exercise NCS test may demonstrate decrementing amplitudes.

Treatment:

Mild attacks usually do not require medical treatment. However, severe attacks of weakness can be improved by the administration of potassium. Oral KCl (0.2–0.4 mmol/kg) can be given every 30 min. Only rarely is IV therapy necessary (e.g., when swallowing problems or vomiting is present).

The long-term goal of therapy is to avoid attacks. Patients should be made aware of the importance of a low-carbohydrate, low-sodium diet, and consequences of intense exercise.

Prophylactic administration of acetazolamide or dichlorphenamide can reduce attacks of periodic weakness. However, in patients with HypoKPP type 2, attacks of weakness can be exacerbated with these medications.

questions.text: Identify the wrongly matched pair of antifungals with its mechanism of action:

choices.text: Flucytosine : Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

questions.solution:
Flucytosine acts by inhibition of fungal DNA synthesis.

It is a pyrimidine antimetabolite. After uptake into fungal cells, fungal cytosine deaminase activates it to 5-fluorouracil, which is an anticancer drug. This is further converted into metabolites that inhibit thymidylate synthase which is necessary for DNA synthesis. Thus fungal DNA synthesis is inhibited. Mammalian cells are spared as they lack cytosine deaminase enzyme.

Flucytosine has clinically useful activity against (3C):

  • Cryptococcus
  • Candida species
  • Agents causing chromoblastomycosis

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of Crohn's disease was brought to the emergency. He complained of sudden onset cold sweats and palpitations. Which among the following is the likely cause of his ECG finding shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given ECG finding shows torsades de pointes, which can occur due to hypomagnesemia (Crohn's disease causes chronic diarrhea which can cause excess GI loss of magnesium).

Torsades de pointes means twisting of points, it implies twisting of the QRS complexes around the isoelectric line of the ECG. It is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that is seen in patients with a prolonged QT interval. 

A prolonged QT interval usually results from prolonged ventricular repolarization (lengthening of T wave). A premature ventricular contraction falling in the elongated T wave can initiate torsades de pointes.

The features of torsades de pointes are:

  • Polymorphic QRS complexes that change in amplitude
  • Cycle length giving an appearance of oscillations around the baseline
  • QT prolongation

Related Pearl: Etiology of Torsade De Pointes

Acquired prolongation of QT interval

Electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia

Drugs

  • Antiarrhythmic drugs
    • Class IA: Quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide
    • Class III: Sotalol, amiodarone (QT prolongation common but torsade ventricular tachycardia is rare), ibutilide, dofetilide, almokalant
  • Antibiotics
    • Macrolides: Erythromycin, clarithromycin, azithromycin
    • Fluoroquinolones: Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin
    • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
    • Clindamycin
    • Pentamidine
    • Chloroquine
    • Antifungals: Ketoconazole, itraconazole
    • Antivirals
    • Antipsychotics
    • Antihistamines

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina.
questions.solution:
The below given image shows extracellular eosinophilic deposits between retinal pigment epithelium(RPE) and bruch's membrane which is suggestive of drusens.

Drusens are seen in dry age related macular degeneration(ARMD) and are composed of lipids, complement factors and other cellular components.

Age related Macular degeneration(ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs.

It is the leading cause of blindness in elderly in developed countries and its risk factors include smoking, exposure to sunlight, hypertension, female gender and nutritional deficiencies.

ARMD generally starts as dry ARMD which is characterized by the presence of drusen and gradually progresses to the advanced form known as wet ARMD whose hallmark is choroidal neovascularization with additional findings such as geographic atrophy of retinal pigmentatory epithelium (RPE) and photoreceptors at the macula. 

Clinical features include loss of central vision, distorted vision(lines seen as wavy) and sudden painless loss of vision as seen in wet ARMD.

On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) the Druscens shows hyperfluorescent spots arranged in ‘stars in the sky’ appearance.

Disease management is by:

  • Preventative measures to delay progression such as cessation of smoking, intake of good nutrition and supplementation of vitamins C,E and zinc.
  • Treatment modalities with intravitreal Anti-VEGF injection- Bevacizumab (avastin) and Ranibizumab (Lucentis), photodynamic therapy (PDT) and submacular surgery.


The below given images show drusens in macular area and FFA depicting the 'stars in sky appearance' of drusens respectively.

Option B: Hard exudates are composed of lipoproteins and lipid laden macrophages. They are yellow waxy looking and arranged in clumps or circinate patterns. They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, hypertensive retinopathy and coat’s disease.

The below given image is that of Hard Exudates.

Option C: Cotton wool spots also known as soft exudates are small whitish fluffy lesions which represent areas of nerve infarcts in the nerve fiber layer of the retina. They are seen in central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), hypertensive retinopathy, diabetic retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy and papilledema.

Option D:Cystoid Macular edema(CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer(Henle's layer) and the inner nuclear layer of the retina.

In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearance and on FFA, flower petal pattern can be seen. Optical coherence tomography(OCT) of CME shows loss of foveal depression and intraretinal cystoid spaces.

The below given OCT image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: A young infant is brought to you with a suspected developmental delay. The child is intently looking at his own hands. You would consider referring this child to a specialist if this milestone persists after ______.
questions.solution:
Between 12 and 20 weeks, the child observes his own hands very intently. This milestone is called hand regard and it should disappear by 20 weeks. Its persistence after 20 weeks is considered abnormal.

In a blind child, however, it may persist beyond 20 weeks normally and is called apparent hand regard.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of malignant melanoma?
questions.solution:
Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common type of malignant melanoma. It usually arises in a pre-existent naevus.

Other types of malignant melanoma include:

  • Nodular melanoma - presents as a nodule, and has the worst prognosis. 
  • Acral lentiginous melanoma - commonly seen over palms and soles. Most common melanoma in dark-skinned individuals.
  • Lentigo maligna melanoma - also known as Hutchinson's melanotic freckle. More commonly seen on sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, or hands of the elderly. It is the least common and has the best prognosis.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following cutaneous finding to the dermatology OPD. Which of the following organisms is least likely to cause this?
questions.solution:
The serpiginous/serpent-like skin lesions seen are cutaneous larva migrans or larva currens. Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are hookworms that cause human infection and are least likely to cause cutaneous larva migrans.

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense, Ancylostoma caninum acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. 

Serpentine or linear single-track lines later mark the course of the larvae as they migrate through the epidermis of the trunk and lower extremities. Symptoms begin to appear within the first two weeks of the patient’s return from a tropical or endemic country. The larval track progresses at approximately 1 cm/h with cutaneous lesions only progressing a few millimeters to a few centimeters daily.

Larva currens aka 'running larva’ of Strongyloidiasis stercoralis. It is known for its distinct rapidity, with the larval track progressing at approximately 0.2 cm/min, with cutaneous lesions progressing up to 10 cm/hour. 

Ivermectin is the preferred treatment and is given at 0.15–0.2 mg/kg every day per oral for 1 or 2 days.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The video clip of a 2-day-old neonate exhibiting repetitive, rhythmic movement in unilateral upper and lower limbs suggests a neonatal seizure of focal clonic type. 

A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, maybe unifocal or multifocal. It may occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body. It may occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides. It cannot be suppressed by restraint. 

Other options: 

Option A: Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Option C: Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. They too cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.

Option D: Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedalling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in preterm than in term babies. 

Myoclonic seizures are random, single, rapid muscle contractions of the limbs, face, or trunk. They are not repetitive or may recur at a slow rate. They can be generalized, focal, or fragmentary. They can be provoked by stimulation.

Clinically apparent seizures in a neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures. In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before starting anti-epileptic drug treatment. 

Causes of neonatal seizure according to the age of presentation: 

1 to 4 days 4 to 14 days 2 to 8 weeks

Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy

Maternal use of narcotics or barbiturates

Drug toxicity: lidocaine, penicillin

Intraventricular hemorrhage

Hypocalcemia, sepsis, hypoglycemia, hypomagnesemia,  hypo or hypernatremia

Galactosemia, urea cycle disorders

Meningitis (bacterial)

Encephalitis (enteroviral, herpes simplex)

Hypocalcemia, hypoglycemia

Galactosemia, fructosemia, 

Hyperinsulinism, hyperammonemia syndrome

Herpes simplex or enteroviral encephalitis, bacterial meningitis

Subdural hematoma, child abuse

Aminoaciduria, urea cycle defects

Malformations of cortical development

Tuberous sclerosis

Sturge-Weber syndrome

questions.text: The drug of choice in anaphylactic shock is?

choices.text: Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.solution:
Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 by intramuscular route (IM) is the drug of choice for treatment of anaphylactic shock. Hence it is the answer here.

In case the patient develops life threatening condition, adrenaline 0.25 mg IV is given.

Note : This is a controversial question. The following inference from journal may help to clarify the concept.

  • As vasodilatation is the main pathological change early in anaphylaxis, this enables the subcutaneous or intramuscular absorption of adrenaline to be rapid and effective.
  • Thus, when the disease is treated early and is progressing slowly, or venous access is difficult or the patient is unmonitored, intramuscular adrenaline has advantages in terms of safety and is usually effective.
  • Later, when intravascular volume is depleted and shock occurs with a life threatening situation, or there is severe dyspnoea or airway compromise, the intravenous route is necessary to achieve optimal absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect of escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Sialorrhoea is not an adverse effect of escitalopram.

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) mainly used to treat major depressive disorder or generalized anxiety disorder.

Nausea is the commonest side effect of SSRIs as they target the 5HT3 receptor.

Vivid dreams may occur because the drug suppresses REM sleep (the stage of dream), hence when patients eventually fall into REM sleep it may be more intense. 

Anorgasmia is the persistent inability to achieve orgasm despite responding to sexual stimulation. A proposed mechanism of escitalopram causing sexual dysfunction involves stimulation of the 5HT2C receptors.

questions.text: The water vapor and pollutants tend to get trapped in the lowermost layers of the atmosphere in winters. What is the reason behind this occurrence?
questions.solution:
In winters, water vapor and pollutants get trapped in the lowermost layers of the atmosphere due to temperature inversion.

This results in the formation of smog, especially in the winter months, and this is a possible threat to human health.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Air pollutants:

Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide Incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulfur dioxide

Colorless gas
Sharp odor
Combustion of sulfur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc
Main components of acid rain.
Lead Usually occupational and environmental sources
Carbon dioxide Increase in a global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely.
Hydrocarbons Cause photochemical smog
Cadmium From volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc
Hydrogen sulfide Waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc
Ozone Ground-level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog.
Oxides of nitrogen Most common form is nitric oxide
From coal burning, road traffic, and electricity generation
Affects the lungs adversely
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc
Carcinogenic and mutagenic
Particulate matter Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter
Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon, and water.
Common indoor air pollutants

From coal or fuel combustion

Include CO, PAHs, nitrogen and sulfur oxides, pesticides, and other biological pollutants


Radon, lead, asbestos are formed from construction materials, paints, and demolition

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide - one of the best indicator of air pollution
  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
  • Grit and dust measurement 
  • The co-efficient of haze - assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air
  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: Which of the following blood vessels in the connecting stalk disappears during development?
questions.solution:
The right vein in the connecting stalk disappears during development. 

At first, the connecting stalk is at the caudal end of the embryonic disc. With the formation of the tail fold, the connecting stalk moves to the ventral part of the embryo, near the area of the umbilical opening. 

The blood vessels connecting the placenta to the embryo pass through the connecting stalk. Initially, there are 2 arteries and 2 veins. Later the right vein disappears (the left vein is left behind). The connecting stalk then consists of 2 arteries and 1 vein.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of a mass descending PV. On examination, you note that the external os lies at the level of the introitus. What is the degree of uterine prolapse?
questions.solution: The given case scenario is suggestive of 2nd degree prolapse.

questions.text: A young man sustained multiple injuries following a road traffic accident. On examination, his pulse rate is 100/min and BP is 85/60 mmHg. He is diagnosed with pelvic fracture and is suspected to have retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of damage control surgery
Definitive repair of injuries is done 12-24 hours after phase III
Internal iliac artery ligation is done in phase II
Hypothermia and acidosis are corrected in phase I

questions.solution:
Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of Damage Control Surgery.

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

It consists of three phases:

  1. Phase I - Initial Exploration: This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active haemorrhage and contamination.
  2. Phase II - Secondary Resuscitation: This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis.
  3. Phase III - Definitive Operation: It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text:
As the medical officer at a blood bank, you are supervising the separation of blood components of donated blood. The preservative used for the packed red cells is SAG-M. Which of the following criteria must be fulfilled in order to safely transfuse this to patients?
  Storage temperature To be used within:
1.    -2° to -6 °C         21 days
2.    +2° to +6 °C       42 days
3.    -2° to -6 °C        35 days
4.    +2° to +6 °C.      48 days
questions.solution:
The shelf life of packed red cells (pRBCs) in the SAG-M solution is 42 days. The optimum temperature for storage of packed RBCs and whole blood collected in preservatives is +2° to +6° C. This temperature maintains the viability of the cells and prevents bacterial contamination.

Blood component  Storage temperature Shelf-life
PRBCs +2° to +6 °C

CPD-21 days

CPD-A-35 days

SAG M-42 days
Platelets +20 to +24 °C 5 days
Fresh frozen plasma -30 °C or lower 1 year
Cryoprecipitate -30 °C or lower 1 years

Related Pearl: Blood components

Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) 300-350 ml RBCs

Hb by 1 g/dl

Hematocrit by 3%

1° to 6°C

ACD/CPD-21 days, CPD-A-35 days, additive-42 days
Random donor platelets (RDP) 50-70 ml Platelets platelet count by 5000-10,000/µL 20 to 24°C 5 days
Single donor apheretic platelets (SDP*) 200-400 ml Platelets platelet count by 30,000/µL

questions.text: During your OBG rotations, one of the senior residents asks you to induce labor in a primigravida admitted at 40 weeks of gestation. Identify the following device that you will use for the same.
questions.solution:
This is an image of a cervidil vaginal insert. It is used for cervical ripening and improves the Bishop's score.

It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone designed to release at a rate of approximately 0.3 mg/hr over 10-hours.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in patients with megaloblastic anaemia?
questions.solution:
The reticulocyte count is decreased in megaloblastic anaemia.

The reticulocyte count is indicative of bone marrow function and its ability to produce healthy erythrocytes. In megaloblastic anemia, there is intramedullary hemolysis leading to raised indirect bilirubin and impaired erythroid maturation leading to a low reticulocyte count.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding basilar skull fractures?

choices.text: Racoon eyes is one of the earliest signs to develop
Battle sign is associated with posterior cranial fossa fractures
CSF leaks should be promptly managed by surgical intervention
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation should be avoided

questions.solution:
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation should be avoided in patients with basilar skull fractures due to the risk of pneumocephalus. 

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa. 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: “Halo” sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and are delayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.

CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF is confirmed by testing for β2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistent leaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.

Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilar skull fractures due to the risk for intracranial placement. NIPPV is avoided due to the risk for pneumocephalus. 

The image below shows the 'battle' sign.

 

The image below shows 'racoon' eyes.

 

The image below shows pneumocephalus.

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: A P1L1 woman presents with constant dribbling of urine. She gives a history of unattended vaginal delivery following a difficult and prolonged labor 3 months back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistulas usually present with:

  • Constant dribbling of urine from the vagina
  • Excoriation in the groin region due to constant leakage of urine
  • History of pelvic surgery, vaginal delivery or prolonged labor
  • Amenorrhea may be present

On examination, the fistula may be visualized by observing urine collection in the vagina. Bimanual examination reveals its fixity and extent.

Note: Ureterovaginal fistulas usually occur following accidental ureteric injury during C-sections in developing countries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen during pregnancy?

choices.text: Pulmonary blood flow is increased by 2,500 mL/min
Blood flow to the skin decreases to 300 mL/min
Blood flow to the uterus increases to 750 mL/min
Renal blood flow increases by 400 mL/min

questions.solution:
The blood flow to the skin and mucous membranes increases during pregnancy to a maximum of 500 mL/min by the 36th week. Symptoms experienced during pregnancy such as increased heat sensation, sweating or having a stuffy nose can be explained by the increased blood flow.

Regional distribution of blood flow during pregnancy:

  • Uterine blood flow - increased from 50 mL/min in the non-pregnant state to about 750 mL near term. 
  • Pulmonary blood flow - increased by 2,500 mL/min.
  • Renal blood flow - increases by 400 mL/min at 16th week and remains at this level till term.

questions.text: Which method is most appropriate when suitable land for waste disposal is available?
questions.solution:
Controlled tipping is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal when suitable land is available.

In this method, waste materials are placed in a trench, compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the day. This method is also called a sanitary landfill. Chemical, bacteriological and physical changes occur in the buried refuse with temperatures rising to over 60 degrees Celsius within 7 days.

Methods used for controlled tipping are:

  • Trench method
  • Ramp method
  • Area method

Sewage farming is also a method of sewage disposal in places where sufficient and suitable land is available. It is also called land treatment or broad irrigation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism presented with increasing abdominal girth and malaise. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was 6 cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies. They are composed of intermediate keratin filaments.

Mallory bodies are also seen in the following conditions:

  • Morbid obesity
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Wilson’s disease
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis

There are several types of cytoskeletal proteins such as microtubules, thin actin filaments, thick myosin filaments, and intermediate filaments (10 nm).

The intermediate filaments provide a flexible intracellular scaffold that organizes the cytoplasm and resists the forces applied to the cell.

They are divided into five classes: 

  • Keratin filaments - characteristic of epithelial cells (forms Mallory Denk bodies)
  • Neurofilaments - neurons (forms neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease)
  • Desmin filaments - muscle cells
  • Vimentin filaments - connective tissue cells
  • Glial filaments - astrocytes

questions.text: A new drug for multiple sclerosis is undergoing clinical trials where its therapeutic efficacy is being confirmed and adverse reactions are being monitored. Which of the following phases is the drug most likely in?
questions.solution:
The confirmation of therapeutic efficacy and monitoring of adverse reactions of a new drug happens in phase III of the clinical trial.

Purpose of phase III: 

  • Confirmation of the effectiveness of the drug in patients with the target disease
  • Monitoring of adverse reactions 

Phase II involves therapeutic exploration which is the evaluation of the efficacy of the drug and dose-ranging (determination of the optimum tolerated dose). 

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

Phase II

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Large or according to study

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Real-world patients

Open-label study

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

Extends from months to 1 year

1–2 years

3–5 years

Unending, after drug approval

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding confounding factor?

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.solution:
A confounding factor is a factor that is associated with both exposure and diseases and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. It can be reduced by matching.

For example, if the study is that a sedentary lifestyle can lead to coronary artery diseases, then age can act as a confounding factor as it is individually linked to both sedentary lifestyle and coronary artery diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of precurrent disinfection?

choices.text: Chlorination of a well by village public health authorities
Disinfection of kidney tray used during delivery of placenta
Disinfection of bed linen after the death of a patient
Disinfection of artery forceps following a surgery

questions.solution:
Chlorination of water in a well is an example of precurrent disinfection. 

Precurrent disinfection refers to prophylactic disinfection prior to discharge of infectious material. This includes pasteurization of milk, chlorination of water and hand washing.

Concurrent disinfection is the application of disinfection methods after discharge of infectious material from a person or soiling. This includes disinfection of urine, faeces, vomit, contaminated linen, clothes, hands.

Terminal disinfection is done after the death of a patient or transfer or after cessation of isolation.

questions.text: How much drug will remain at the end of 6 hours when a patient is given 200 mg drug, 75 mg excreted in 90 min and if the drug follows first-order kinetics?
questions.solution:
In first order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

Since 75 mg of 200 mg is excreted in 90 minutes, the fraction of drug excreted in each 90 mins is 75/200, which is 3/8. Thus, the fraction of the drug that remains in the body is 5/8. 

There will be 4 cycles of excretion of the drug (6 hours = 360 mins, and 360/90 = 4). Thus, with a starting dose of 200mg, the drug remaining in the body after 4 hours will be:

200 x 5/8 x 5/8 x 5/8 x 5/8 = 30.5mg

Alternate way to calculate: 

75 mg of 200 mg is excreted in 90 minutes, thus 75/200 = 0.375 is eliminated 

After 90 minutes; 200 mg-75 mg = 125 mg remains.
The second 90 minutes (after 180 minutes) = 125 x 0.375 = 46.875 mg is eliminated, and 125-46.875 = 78.125 mg remains
The third 90 minutes (after 270 minutes) = 78.125 x 0.375 = 29.297 mg is eliminated, and 78.125-29.297 = 48.828 remains
The fourth 90 minutes (after 360 minutes) = 48.828 x 0.375 = 18.310 mg is eliminated, 48.828-18.310 = 30.518 mg remains after 6 hours. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: What is the intensity of sound produced during whispering?
questions.solution:
Whispering produces a sound of 20 – 30 dB.

Loudness or intensity depends upon the amplitude of vibrations. It is expressed in decibels (dB). The intensity of sounds produced during various activities is listed below.

Source Loudness
Whispering 20 – 30 dB
Normal conversation 60 – 65 dB
Heavy street traffic 60 – 80 dB
Boiler factories 120 dB

The frequency of sound is expressed in hertz (Hz). The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue is as given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with:

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal centre may be seen
  • Hurthle (Askanazy) cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.

Clinical features:

  • Most prevalent between 45-65 years of age
  • More common in females
  • Painless enlargement of the thyroid
  • Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.

Diagnosis:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid receptors
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and the development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predispose to papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Other options: 

Option A: Histological features of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid include polygonal to spindle-shaped cells in the form of nests, trabeculae or follicles. Small, round anaplastic cells may be found in some cases and amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma.

The given slide below shows medullary carcinoma of thyroid:

Option C: Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism due to circulating autoantibodies. The thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins bind to the TSH receptors, causing overgrowth of the thyroid gland and increased thyroid hormone synthesis. Histologically, there is acinar cell hypertrophy and hyperplasia with the absence of normal colloid in the tall columnar epithelium (normally the epithelium is flat with colloid). Lymphoid infiltrates, consisting predominantly of T cells, along with scattered B cells and mature plasma cells, are present throughout the interstitium. Germinal centers are common.

The given slide below shows Grave's disease:

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in some autoimmune thyroid disorders

Antibody Disorder
TSH receptor-stimulating Immunoglobulins (TSI) Graves disease
Anti TPO & Anti Tg antibodies Chronic lymphocytic(Hashimoto) thyroiditis

TRBAb

(maternal transmission)

 Transient congenital hypothyroidism (maternal autoimmune thyroid disease)
  • Anti TPO – Anti thyroperoxidase antibody
  • Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody
  • TRBAb – TSH receptor blocking antibodies

questions.text: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with sudden onset difficulty in micturition and defaecation. There was no history of a cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of cauda equina syndrome (CES).

CES signifies an injury of multiple lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal distal to the termination of the spinal cord at L1-L2. It is commonly due to a ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disk, lumbosacral spine fracture, hematoma within the spinal canal, compressive tumor, or other mass lesions.

Low back pain, weakness, and areflexia in the legs, saddle anesthesia, or loss of bladder function may occur. 

Treatment options include surgical decompression, sometimes urgently in an attempt to restore or preserve motor or sphincter function, or radiotherapy for metastatic tumors.

Related Pearl: Conus medullaris syndrome vs Cauda equina syndrome

 

Conus medullaris syndrome

Cauda equina syndrome
Injury

Vertebral column injuries between T12 and L2

 Vertebral column injuries distal to L2
Pathophysiology

Upper and lower motor neuron involvement

 Lower motor neuron involvement
Motor strength 

Symmetrical motor impairment 

 Asymmetrical motor impairment
Reflexes Knee jerk preserved, ankle jerk affected Both knee and ankle jerk affected
Sphincter dysfunction Urinary retention presents early in the disease course Urinary retention presents late in the disease course
 

Absent bulbocavernosus reflex
 

Radicular pain and low back pain

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with a painful ear swelling as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of painful, erythematous ear swelling is suggestive of perichondritis.

The most common cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non-iatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. The most common organism responsible is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

The image given below shows a patient with a cauliflower ear deformity. It is also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear. It is usually caused by repeated episodes of trauma.

 

Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis is a small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear. It is shown in the image below. 

 

Otitis externa, also called swimmer's ear, is the inflammation of the ear canal. It has the following appearance:

Related Pearl: Eponyms of the ear

Eponym

Description

Boxer’s/ Cauliflower ear

Organized hematoma of pinna

Surfer’s ear

Exostosis

Swimmer’s ear

Diffuse otitis externa

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with muscle weakness, vomiting, and seizures accompanied by focal neurological deficits. Her developmental milestones were normal during the previous visits. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and microscopic findings of muscle biopsy are shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with microscopy showing ragged red fibres is suggestive of MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke).

It is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to complex I or complex IV deficiency. Patients have normal development previously and then present with symptoms of lactic acidosis and stroke (seizures with focal neurological deficits).

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead) as shown below.

Other mitochondrial inherited diseases:

  • Leigh’s disease
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
  • Kearns–Sayre syndrome
  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia
  • Pearson syndrome

questions.text: An infant was admitted with failure to thrive. His reports show hypoglycemia, high glutamine, and uracil levels in urine. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated and the child became comatose.  Parenteral dextrose was given after which the child recovered in 24 hours. What is the likely enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
This infant with failure to thrive, hypoglycemia, elevated levels of glutamine and uracil levels most likely has hyperammonemia type 2. This condition occurs due to the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.

There is an accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters into pyrimidine synthesis producing orotic acid and uracil and leading to orotic aciduria and high uracil in blood and urine. Since the ammonia from glutamine is not converted into urea, its level increases. Glutamate is not regenerated. Since glutamate is not available for transamination, amino acids cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Hence, the glucose level drops in the blood.

Treatment:

  • Reducing intake of ammonia - Dietary protein, a metabolic source of ammonium, is restricted and caloric intake is provided by glucose and fat.
  • Increasing excretion of ammonia - Addition of phenylbutyrate, which scavenges nitrogen by combining with amino acids to form a more water-soluble product. This can be easily excreted by the kidneys.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A young woman presented to the OPD with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. She was diagnosed with iron deficiency anaemia 3 months back. Barium swallow was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing esophageal web is suggestive of Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome. It commonly affects middle-aged women with long-standing anaemia, and is a recognized risk factor for post-cricoid hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma. It consists of dysphagia, iron-deficiency anemia and esophageal webs or hypopharyngeal webs. 

Esophageal webs are due to a constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen. More commonly, they are seen in the cervical esophagus near the cricopharyngeus muscle. They typically arise from the anterior wall, but never from the posterior wall. They may also be circumferential.

The image below depicts a barium swallow showing an upper esophageal concentric web in a lateral view. 

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: Patients with metachromatic leukodystrophy will have which of the following enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive condition caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase A.

The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of cerebroside sulfate. These sulfatides can contribute to white matter injury, demyelination, and gliosis.

Macrophages with vacuolated cytoplasm are scattered throughout the white matter. They contain metachromatic material, which can be detected in the urine and peripheral nerves when stained with toluidine blue.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about type 4 renal tubular acidosis?

choices.text: The most common cause is diabetes mellitus
It can occurs in patients with interstitial renal diseases
It is caused by hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism

questions.solution:
Type 4 renal tubular acidosis can be a congenital or acquired disorder.

It is caused by conditions that result in hypoaldosteronism or hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism including:

  • Diabetic nephropathy - most common
  • Tubulointerstitial disease 
  • Addison's disease
  • Obstructive uropathy
  • Drugs like NSAIDs, ACEI, ARBs can increase the risk
  • Psuedohypoaldosteronism type 1 (due to aldosterone resistance)
  • Psuedohypoaldosteronism type 2/ gordons syndrome (due to defects in Na-Cl cotransporter) 
  • Congenital isolated hypoaldosteronism (due to enzyme deficiency)

questions.text: A 39-year-old nulliparous woman presented with dysmenorrhea and a progressively growing, painless abdominal mass. USG scan revealed a cystic lesion of the left ovary which was excised. The below image shows the excised specimen. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in endometriosis of ovary
It is lined by columnar epithelium
It is usually a bilateral condition
It is a malignant cystic lesion

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image is suggestive of a chocolate cyst of the ovary which is a benign cystic lesion.

Chocolate cysts of the ovary are a manifestation of endometriosis. Both the ovaries are usually affected. On histology, the cyst is lined by columnar epithelium. Pseudoxanthoma cells are present which are large macrophages or scavenger cells that appear brown in colour due to ingested blood pigments such as ­haemosiderin. They are polyhe­dral in shape and resemble lutein cells. 

Given below is a gross image of the chocolate cyst of the ovary.

Given below is a histopathological section of an endometriotic lesion showing the pseudoxanthoma cells.

questions.text: While studying a disease, you find that it affects both humans and lower vertebrates and can be transmitted in either direction. How would you classify this disease?
questions.solution:
A disease that affects both humans and lower vertebrates and which can be transmitted in either direction is classified as amphixenosis. E.g, Trypanosoma cruzi and Schistosoma japonicum.

It is a type of zoonoses. Zoonoses are diseases that are transmitted between vertebrate animals and humans.

Other types of zoonoses include:            

  • Anthropozoonoses - infections that are transmitted to man from vertebrates. E.g., Rabies, plague etc.
  • Zooanthroponoses - infections that are transmitted to vertebrates from humans. E.g., Human tuberculosis in cattle.

Epizootic disease refers to an outbreak or epidemic of a disease in an animal population, often with the implication that it may also affect human populations. Enzootic disease is an endemic occurring in animals.

Note: Epornithic diseases are those diseases which are epidemic in bird populations. E.g., Psittacosis.

questions.text: A 40 year old woman has a history of urinating in public without having any remorse for it. She also has difficulty getting motivated and has mild memory deficits. Which of the following lobes would be affected?
questions.solution:
Frontal lobe is affected in this patient.

The woman has difficulty in getting motivated, memory deficits and urinary incontinence.

Frontal lobe injury:

  • Impairs the executive functions: motivation, attention, and sequencing of actions
  • Aphasia, neglect, and memory deficits can be seen
  • Characterized by changes in personality
  • Apathetic indifference and impulsive behaviour.
  • Commonly urinary incontinence and fecal incontinence is seen
  • Commonly produced by trauma, infarcts, tumors, lobotomy, multiple sclerosis, or Pick's disease.

Frontal lobe pathology may become apparent only under unstructured, stressful, real-life situations and are difficult to detect in Intelligence scales, as IQ mostly requires parietal lobe activation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about fibroids?

choices.text: More common in Asians than African-Americans
Does not usually increase in size during pregnancy

questions.solution:
Fibroids are more common in African-American women.

Uterine fibroids are benign, smooth muscle tumors present in the uterine musculature. They are most commonly seen during reproductive years. Estrogen and progesterone promote the development of fibroids.

Option B: Hypoestrogenism occurs in smokers, therefore smoking is protective for fibroids.

Option C: Estrogen exposure is increased in nulliparous women, therefore fibroids are more common. Increased parity is protective for fibroids.

Option D: Most fibroids do not increase in size during pregnancy. Pregnancy can have an unpredictable effect on fibroids based on individual genetic and environmental factors.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

questions.text: Patients with which of the following can be classified under smoldering multiple myeloma?

choices.text: Lack of symptoms and a high plasma M component with bone marrow plasma cells >10%
Plasma cells >10% in the bone marrow, no paraprotein in blood and presence of lytic bone lesions
Plasma cells >10% in bone marrow, abnormal serum free light chain ratio and hypercalcemia
Presence of symptoms and a low plasma M component with plasma cells <10%

questions.solution:
Smoldering multiple myeloma refers to an uncommon variant defined by a lack of symptoms and a high plasma M component.

The difference between MGUS, smouldering multiple myeloma, and multiple myeloma is given below:

MGUS Smouldering multiple Myeloma Multiple Myeloma
Asymptomatic Asymptomatic Symptomatic
M protein in serum <3g/dL

M-protein in serum:

  • IgG ≥3 g/dL,
  • IgA >1 g/dL
 M protein in serum and urine
Bone Marrow (BM) plasma cells <10% BM plasma cells 10-60% BM plasma cells ≥60%
No other organ or tissue impairment No other organ or tissue impairment Related impairment is seen.
(CRAB)

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 3g/dL and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment

Plasmacytoma

questions.text: A worried mother brings her febrile infant to the ER. He is crying incessantly and clutching his ear. He had the following finding on otoscopy. What is the most likely organism implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image showing congested tympanic membrane with purulent effusion and absent cone of light is suggestive of acute suppurative otitis media. The most likely organism implicated is Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Organisms causing ASOM in infants and young children:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae 
  • Moraxella catarrhalis 
  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: You prescribe an antibiotic course for a patient following cesarean section. What advice would you give regarding breastfeeding?

choices.text: No advice as most of drug are not present in breast milk
Avoid breastfeeding during the antibiotic course
Medications to be taken 3-4 hours before next feeding

questions.solution:
If the lactating mother needs to take medications that are deemed safe, the optimal dosing time should be 30-60 minutes after nursing and at least 3-4 hours before the next feeding.

A minimum interval of 3-4 hours allows time for partial clearance of the drug. This ensures the infants are not exposed to the peak maternal plasma concentration that may translate to higher levels secreted into milk. 

Other options: 

Option A: Most drugs administered are detected in breast milk, but most of them are excreted in very small quantities that do not cause any effect in the infants. 

Option B: Breastfeeding should not be avoided altogether for all medications. Intake of cytotoxic agents and immunomodulatory agents are contraindications for breastfeeding. 

Option D: The timing of medication should preferably be at an interval where the infants are not exposed to higher maternal plasma concentrations.

questions.text: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case?

choices.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of nitrates in prinzmetal angina is endothelium-independent coronary vasodilatation.

Prinzmetal angina occurs due to vasospasm of the coronary arteries. Nitrates relax the smooth muscles of epicardial coronary arteries and relieve coronary artery spasm.

In the case of stable angina, the primary mechanism of action of nitrates is preferential dilatation of veins (by increasing cGMP). Venous dilatation leads to a decrease in the venous return to the heart (preload). This decreases the ventricular end-diastolic volume and thereby a decrease in myocardial oxygen consumption. The diastolic perfusion pressure (aortic blood pressure in diastole - left ventricular pressure in diastole) is increased.

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is ________
questions.solution:
The GCS in this patient is 11.

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to only painful stimuli.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain. 

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text:
Arrange the following sites of ectopic pregnancy from the most common to the least common.
  1. Interstitium
  2. Isthmus
  3. Ampulla
  4. Fimbriae
questions.solution:
The order of the most common site to the least common site in the fallopian tube for ectopic pregnancy is ampulla>isthmus>fimbriae>interstitium.

An ectopic pregnancy is any pregnancy implanted outside of the endometrial cavity.

Extrauterine sites: The most common site of ectopic pregnancy is the extrauterine fallopian tube. 

  • Tubal - 97% (most common)
    • Ampulla - 55%
    • Isthmus
    • Infundibulum
    • Interstitium
  • Ovarian
  • Abdominal

Intrauterine ectopic sites:

  • Cervical
  • Caesarean scar 
  • Rudimentary horn of a bicornuate uterus
  • Heterotopic pregnancy

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a family history of hearing loss in her mother developed a hearing problem during pregnancy. Hearing loss is bilateral and progressive. Which of the following is the single best investigation to establish a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the single best investigation to diagnose otosclerosis is impedance audiometry.

Option B- In pure tone audiometry (PTA), Carhart's notch with an air-bone gap indicates otosclerosis.

Option C- MRI is usually not done. HRCT is the preferred imaging modality for otosclerosis.  

Option D- Schwabach’s test is a tuning fork test that shows conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A newspaper editor discloses the identity of a victim of rape without prior permission. He would be tried under which of the following sections?
questions.solution:
Section 72 of BNS (IPC Section 228A) deals with punishment for disclosure of the identity of the victim of rape.

Other options:

Option A: Section 71 BNS (IPC 376E) deals with repeat offenders.

Option C: Section 73 BNS (IPC 228A (3)) deals with printing or publishing any matter relating to court proceedings without permission.

Option D: Section 74 BNS (IPC 354) deals with the assault or use of criminal force on a woman with intent to outrage her modesty.

questions.text:
ABG analysis of a patient is shown below. What is the probable underlying acid-base disorder in this patient?

pH- 7.1

pCO2- 16 mmHg

HCO3- - 6 mEq/L

pO2- 78 mmHg

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis. 

Step 3: pCO2 is 16 mmHg indicating respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in pCO2 along with the decrease in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula (Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2).

Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19 mmHg

A pCO2 level of 16 mmHg falls within the range given above. Hence, metabolic acidosis is associated with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

(pCO2 values above or below 15 - 19 mmHg would indicate mixed acid-base disorders)

Alternatively:

The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.2 mmHg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.

The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L

Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.2 = 22

Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22 = 18 mmHg (roughly = 16 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)

This method also indicates primary metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. However, Winter's formula is more accurate.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

questions.text: You initiate iron and folic acid supplements for a woman at 13 weeks of gestation. According to the ministry of health & family welfare (MoHFW), what is the minimum duration for which she should take these supplements?
questions.solution:
The guideline recommends 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 μg of folic acid daily for at least 180 days, starting from the 4th month of pregnancy, and to be continued throughout pregnancy. Ideally, this must be continued until 180 days postpartum.

In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following depicts the correct sequence of enzymes involved in glycogenolysis in the liver?
questions.solution:
The sequence of enzymes involved in steps of glycogenolysis is phosphorylase, glucan transferase, and glucose-6-phosphatase.

Related Pearl: Glycogenolysis

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with migratory arthralgia and a malar skin rash that is exacerbated by sun exposure. Her urinalysis shows moderate proteinuria and red blood cell casts and she had leucopenia. Serum auto-antibodies with high specificity for this patient’s condition react with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The autoantibodies (anti-ds-DNA) react with double-stranded DNA.

SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs, characterized by a vast array of autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANAs). The injury is caused mainly by the deposition of immune complexes and the binding of antibodies to various cells and tissues.

Option A: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are specific for primary biliary cirrhosis.

Option B: Rheumatoid factor is an IgM antibody directed against the Fc fragment of self-IgG. It is found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis and other collagen tissue disorders.

Option C: Anti-centromere antibodies are present in the majority of patients with CREST syndrome.
