questions.text: An asymptomatic 30-year-old man presents with a lesion on his thigh as seen in the below image. He returned a week ago from the US where he inspected farming areas during the summer. The best management for this patient would be:

choices.text: Reassurance as it is a fixed drug eruption

questions.solution:
The given image classically depicts the bull’s eye lesion (erythema chronicum migrans) and the clinical history is suggestive of the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The drug of choice for early asymptomatic Lyme disease is Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

Lyme disease is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the hard tick, Ixodes. It usually occurs after a tick bite while strolling through the farms. Most of them do not recall the bite and the initial presentation is only a skin lesion known as erythema chronicum migrans.

It is only after dissemination, that the disease spreads to joints (arthritis), heart (AV blocks), and the nervous system (neuroborreliosis).

The treatment protocol for early Lyme disease includes:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD (Drug of choice) for 2-3 weeks (or)
  • Amoxicillin 500 – 1000 mg for 2-3 weeks (for children < 9 years, pregnant women)

In severe disseminated cases, Ceftriaxone 2 g IV for 2-3 weeks can be given. 

Other options:

Option A - Chloroquine and tafenoquine are used to prevent Plasmodium vivax malaria relapse. There are no clinical symptoms suggestive of Malaria. 

Option C - Antihistamines can be used to treat urticaria. Patients present with short-lived itchy weals, angioedema, or both. 

Option D - Fixed drug eruption presents as a sharply defined oval or round erythematous, edematous plaque. It becomes dusky, violaceous, and vesicular or bullous. It occurs in the lips, genitals, palms, and soles.

questions.text: A person complains of severe pain after he fell backwards on his elbow. His X-ray is shown below. What is the preferred treatment in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a displaced transverse fracture of the olecranon. Tension band wiring is one of the management methods in this case. 

The Mayo classification divides olecranon fractures into three groups based on fracture displacement and elbow stability. Each group is further subdivided into comminuted or noncomminuted fractures. 

  • Type I - Undisplaced fractures
  • Type II - Displaced but stable fractures
  • Type III - Unstable fractures

Treatment includes:

  • Type I fractures - non-operative management
  • Type II and III fractures - surgery
  • Simple fractures without comminution or instability - tension band wiring, plate fixation, or an intramedullary rod
  • Comminuted fractures and fractures with elbow instability - plate fixation 
  • Osteoporotic patients with significant comminution - excision of the olecranon and triceps advancement

Related Pearl: Tension Band Wiring

A tension band wire is a form of internal fixation used to convert distraction forces into compression forces, promoting bone healing.

It is used in:

  • Fracture patella
  • Fracture olecranon 
  • Fracture lateral malleolus
  • Fracture greater trochanter

The below image shows tension band wiring for a fracture olecranon

questions.text: You are a resident posted in the medicine ward. A patient who has been previously diagnosed with epilepsy has an episode of seizures and becomes unconscious. You immediately call a code. The patient is unresponsive and chest rise is not appreciable but you can feel a pulse. You suspect that this is due to falling back of the tongue and decide to secure the airway using the device shown. What landmarks would you use before selecting the appropriate size?

choices.text: Incisor teeth and tragus of the ear
Corner of mouth and angle of mandible
Tip of nose and angle of mandible
Ala of nose and angle of mandible

questions.solution:
The image shows oropharyngeal airway or Guedel airway of various sizes. The landmarks used for measuring the appropriate size of this device are the corner of the mouth and the angle of the mandible or tragus.

An oropharyngeal airway is an airway adjunct which keeps the tongue from falling back onto the posterior pharynx.

It is essential to choose the correct size since inappropriately sized ones may aggravate airway obstruction. 

These airways should not be used in conscious patients as they may come into contact with the epiglottis and base of tongue. This can cause coughing, retching or laryngospasm if the pharyngeal and laryngeal reflexes are not blunted with local anaesthetic. 

Note: Nasopharyngeal airway size is chosen by measuring the distance between the tip of the nose and tragus of the ear. These airways, when well lubricated and inserted with proper technique, can be used in conscious patients to secure an airway.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false regarding papillary thyroid carcinomas?

choices.text: p53 mutation is associated with a good prognosis
Occult carcinomas are not associated with capsule invasion

questions.solution:
p53 mutation is associated with a poor prognosis. 

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas, children and radiation exposed areas. 
  • Near-total or total thyroidectomy is indicated for all tumours >1 cm in size.
  • Thyroid lobectomy alone is considered sufficient treatment for small (<1 cm) tumours. 
  • Minimal or occult malignancy refers to tumours <1 cm in size, with no capsular invasion or angioinvasion, or lymph node metastasis. 

 

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is popularly used in clinical anaesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Ulnar nerve stimulation at wrist is popularly used to assess the adequacy of neuromuscular blockade.

Neuromuscular blockade is measured using a peripheral nerve stimulator.

Nerve Response
Ulnar nerve Contraction of adductor pollicis
Facial nerve Contraction of orbicularis oculi
Posterior tibial nerve Contraction of flexor hallucis brevis

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman at 30 weeks of gestation was rushed to the casualty with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding. She had woken up to find herself in a pool of blood. On examination, her vitals were unstable. Active bleeding per vaginum was present. Which of the following complications would not be anticipated in her?
questions.solution:
Then given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa and precipitate labour is not a complication. Precipitate labour is seen in abruptio placenta and uterine tachysystole.

Vaginal bleeding in placenta previa is sudden in onset, recurrent, painless, unrelated to activity, and often occurs during sleep.

Complications of placenta previa: 

Maternal complications:

Period Complication
Antepartum

Antepartum haemorrhage

Malpresentation

Preterm labour
Intrapartum

Early rupture of membranes

Slow dilatation of cervix
Postpartum Postpartum haemorrhage
Puerperium

Sepsis

Subinvolution

Fetal complications:

  • Low birth weight
  • Asphyxia
  • Intrauterine death
  • Birth injuries
  • Congenital malformations.

questions.text: Cardiovascular effect of this new drug(X) that activates autonomic receptors is shown below.The most probable receptor affinities of the new drug(X) are
questions.solution:
A decrease in mean blood pressure, an increase in pulse pressure, plus a marked increase in heart rate are characteristic of a drug such as isoproterenol.  

It has receptor affinities for β1, β2.  

PVR and mean BP are decreased because of activation of β2 receptors in the vasculature.  

Systolic BP remains the same or increases because of activation of β1 receptors in the heart, leading to an increase in stroke volume, as well as the increase in heart rate.

questions.text: In a case of acute exacerbation of asthma, salbutamol was given, however, no improvement was noticed. Intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were given and the condition improved. What is the probable mechanism by which the corticosteroids would have improved the condition?

choices.text: Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthines
Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthines on adenosine receptor

questions.solution:
Corticosteroids improved the condition by increasing the airway responsiveness to salbutamol.

Mechanism of action of corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to β-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of β-2 receptor genes and hence increases responsiveness to β-2 agonists.

β-2 agonists increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors.

Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating the enzyme histone deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

Note: As per recent GINA 2021 guidelines, aminophyllines are no longer preferred in the management of acute severe asthma due to their low efficacy and poor safety profile.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The marked structure is incus.

This is an image taken during mastoidectomy. The incus articulates with the malleus and has a short process and a long process. The long process articulates with the head of the stapes.

CT: chorda tympani; I: incus; JB: jugular bulb; LSC: lateral semicirular canal; M: malleus; PSC: posterior semicircular canal; S: stapes; SM: stapedius muscle; SSC: superior semicircular canal; VIIms: mastoid segment of VII cranial nerve; VIIts: tympanic segment of VII cranial nerve.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and Fluorescein angiography findings of neovascularization are suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).

Neovascularization is a hallmark of PDR. So this rules out Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy-NPDR (Option A,B).

Option C: Birdshot retinochoroidopathy is an idiopathic bilateral chorioretinitis characterized by creamy yellow spots of chorioretinal hypopigmentation resembling a birdshot scatter. It most commonly affects middle aged females who are HLA-A29 positive.

PDR is most common in patients with Type Ⅰ diabetes after a period of 15-20 years and is characterized by proliferation of new vessels at the optic disc (NVD) or elsewhere in the fundus (NVE).

( NVD- neovascularization at the optic disc ; NVE-neovascularization elsewhere in the fundus )

Complications of PDR include recurrent vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment and pre retinal hemorrhages.

It is treated by administration of Anti-VEGF drugs followed by pan retinal photocoagulation which destroys the hypoxic retina that has been producing the vasoformative factors responsible for neovascularization.

Duration of diabetes mellitus is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy.

Ophthalmoscopic features of NPDR include:

  • Microaneurysms: due to loss of pericytes around the capillaries
  • Retinal hemorrhages: both superficial (flame shaped) and deep (dot & blot) hemorrhages.
  • Hard exudates: composed of lipoproteins and lipid laden macrophages. They are yellow waxy looking and arranged in clumps or circinate patterns.
  • Cotton wool spots: which are small whitish fluffy lesions which represent areas of nerve infarct.
  • Intra retinal microvascular abnormalities(IRMA): are arteriovenous shunts in retina
  • Venous abnormalities such as beading,looping and dilatation.

The below given image is that of Hard Exudates.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A senior casualty nurse informs you that a 5-year-old girl with severe respiratory distress might require intubation. You just finished stabilising and placing an ET tube in Mohan, a 57-year-old man with head trauma and a GCS of 7. Which of the following is not a feature of child's airway?

choices.text: The larynx being located higher in the neck at the level of C3-C4
The narrowest part being the subglottic region

questions.solution:
The pediatric airway is funnel shaped. In comparison, the adult airway is cylindrical.

In newborns, the larynx is situated at the level of C3-C4, where it facilitates simultaneous respiration and swallowing during feeding.

questions.text: A farmer residing in West Bengal brings his 16-month-old child to the OPD for routine immunization. The child has been adequately immunized till now and has already received a measles vaccine during a supplementary immunization activity drive a few months back. What will you administer to him now?

choices.text: OPV booster, DPT booster and Vitamin A
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, JE and Vitamin A
OPV booster, DPT booster, JE vaccine and Vitamin A
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR and Vitamin A

questions.solution:
Vaccines to be given at 16 months of age are OPV booster, DPT booster, MR, JE, and Vitamin A.

The child should receive routine doses of the measles vaccine according to the schedule irrespective of the measles supplementary immunisation activity (SIA) dose. So, the second dose of the measles vaccine is also given.

Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is endemic in rural agricultural areas, often associated with rice cultivation and flood irrigation. Vaccination for JE is given in endemic states only. Two doses of a live attenuated JE vaccine are given under the Universal Immunisation Programme (UIP) schedule. Under the Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) schedule, two doses of a new vero cell-derived inactivated JE vaccine are given.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is diagnosed to have Stage II (A) Hodgkin's lymphoma. What staging system was most likely used to classify the tumor of this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical staging of both Hodgkin and Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is done by Ann-Arbor classification. 

Option B: Masaoka staging is used for thymoma.

Option C: Modified Durie–Salmon staging is used for multiple myeloma. 

 

Related Pearl: Ann Arbor Staging for Hodgkin and NonHodgkin Lymphoma

Stage Distribution of disease
I

Involvement of a single lymph node region (I)

or 

a single extra lymphatic organ or site (IE)
II

Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm alone (II)

or

localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site (IIE)
III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm without (III) or with (IIIE) localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site
IV

Diffuse involvement of one or more extra lymphatic organs or sites with or without lymphatic involvement 

All stages are further divided on the basis of the absence (A) or presence (B) of fever, night sweats and/or unexplained weight loss >10% of body weight.

questions.text: The following antigen is produced by all of the following pathogens except__________.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Superantigen. Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. This means they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocaspid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.
  • Fungal
    • Malassezia furfur.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS).

The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below.

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

VEXAS syndrome (vacuoles, E1 enzyme, X-linked, autoinflammatory, somatic) is a Novel disorder discovered in 2020. It is an adult-onset inflammatory disease with clinical features that bridge rheumatologic & hematologic conditions. VEXAS may be a prototype for new class of “hematoinflammatory diseases.” These diseases would be defined by somatic mutations in hematopoietic cells, systemic inflammation, & potential to evolve into overt myelodysplastic, myeloproliferative, or lymphoproliferative disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has undergone a total thyroidectomy procedure and has been shifted to the post-op ward. 2 hours later she develops stridor and dyspnea, but her voice is normal. Which of the following vocal cord lesions is the most likely cause for her condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture of stridor and dyspnea with a normal voice is most likely due to bilateral abductor paralysis (B/L RLN injury). It is the most dangerous vocal cord lesion.

All the other options will have an abnormality in the voice. Normal voice is seen only in B/L RLN injury.  

In bilateral abductor paralysis,

  • Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position, the airway is inadequate causing dyspnea and stridor. This may lead to death if untreated.
  • The voice is good.
  • Dyspnea and stridor become worse on exertion or during an attack of acute laryngitis.

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by the  following vector that is found in cracks and crevices of walls in the day time?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a sandfly. It transmits visceral leishmaniasis.

Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases:

  • Kala-azar
  • Oriental sore
  • Sandfly fever
  • Oroya fever

Japanese encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Dengue is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.

Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is caused by the mutation of the transthyretin protein?
questions.solution:
Familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy (FAP) is associated with the deposition of mutant transthyretin protein (TTR). 

FAP is an autosomal dominant condition. The deposition occurs as amyloid fibrils in peripheral and autonomic nerves. Mutated TTR is prone to misfolding and aggregation, and shows resistance to proteolysis.

Systemic senile amyloidosis (amyloid of aging) refers to the systemic deposition of normal TTR amyloid in elderly patients. Symptomatic patients present with restrictive cardiomyopathy and arrhythmias. Another rare form affecting predominantly the heart results from the deposition of a mutant form of TTR.

Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is an autosomal-recessive condition seen in individuals of Mediterranean descent (Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic). The affected gene encodes a protein called pyrin, which is involved in cytokine production. The amyloid fibril proteins in this condition are made up of AA proteins. It presents with attacks of fever and serositis. 

Isolated atrial amyloidosis is associated with AANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) amyloid deposition

questions.text: A mother noticed yellowish discoloration of her term newborn within the first 6 hours of life. On examination, jaundice extended up to the lower abdomen and thighs. Which of the following drugs can be administered along with phototherapy?
questions.solution:
Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for pathological jaundice in neonates.

It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy.

Tolazoline is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that produces systemic and pulmonary vasodilatation, which is used to correct pulmonary artery vasospasm when it causes severe right-left shunting soon after birth.

Tromethamine is an organic buffer used in the management of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by dark ground microscopy. 

Treponemes are short and slender with regular and sharp spirals. 

Other options:

Option A: Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends as shown in the image below

Option C: Borrelia are large with irregular and wide open coils.

Option D: Helicobacter pylori is a spiral rod (bacilli) that is not classified as a spirochete.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following complement deficiencies are at an increased risk of developing systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
C1q complement deficiency is a risk factor for the development of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). 

Risk factors for SLE are:

  • Genetic
    • Genetic defects resulting in C1q, C2, C4 complement deficiencies
    • Presence of HLA DR3
    • Mutation in the TREX1 gene
  • Environmental
    • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection
    • Oral contraceptive pills/ hormone replacement therapy
    • Smoking
    • Prolonged exposure to silica

Related Pearl: Complement deficiency and associated diseases

questions.text: All are true about fibromuscular dysplasia except that_____.

choices.text: It affects  thickening in medium and large muscular arteries.
“String of beads” appearance is seen on angiography.
It is associated with the use of oral contraceptives.

questions.solution:
Although fibromuscular dysplasia is seen most frequently in young women, there is no association with oral contraceptives or increased estrogen expression.

  • Fibromuscular dysplasia is a focal irregular thickening in medium and large muscular arteries, involves renal, carotid, splanchnic, and vertebral vessels.
  • The cause is probably developmental.
  • First-degree relatives of affected individuals have an increased incidence.
  • Segments of the vessel wall are focally thickened by a combination of medial and intimal hyperplasia and fibrosis, resulting in luminal stenosis.
  • In the renal arteries, this can be a cause of renovascular hypertension.
  • On angiography, the vessels are said to have a “string of beads” appearance as shown below.

questions.text: In a cardiac arrest patient, if intravenous access cannot be obtained, what is the next best way to administer epinephrine?

choices.text: Wait till intravenous access is made

questions.solution:
American Heart Association recommends the intraosseous (IO) route as an alternative to an intravenous route in order to deliver drugs and fluids, especially in children.

This is because intraosseous access can easily be made in 30-60 seconds and thus provide emergency vascular access. It involves placing a catheter into the marrow venous plexus and administering, crystalloids, colloids, drugs, and blood which leads to rapid and reliable absorption into the systemic circulation.

Sites of choice: proximal tibia, distal femur, the distal end of radius, or ulna.

The fluids are administered under pressure because of the resistance to fluid flow from the IO catheter into the IO space. The disadvantage with this route is the risk of osteomyelitis, compartment syndrome, bone marrow or fat embolism.

IO access is superior to the endotracheal route. The American Heart Association does not recommend an intramuscular route for cardiac resuscitation.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the resting length of a muscle fiber except ________.

choices.text: There are maximum cross-bridges between actin and myosin
The resting length is around 2μm in humans
The velocity of contraction is maximum for any given load

questions.solution:
The passive tension is not maximum at resting length of a muscle fiber.

Passive tension is the tension in a muscle when it is not stimulated. Total tension is the tension developed when a muscle contracts isometrically in response to a maximal stimulus.

Active tension = Total tension - Passive tension

The active tension is maximum at the resting length of a muscle fiber. This is because there is a optimal overlap between the actin and myosin fibers at the resting length and therefore the maximum number of cross-bridges are formed. (Option A) This provides for the maximum force of contraction at this length. The active tension decreases as the muscle is stretched beyond its normal length. The resting length is around 2μm in humans. (Option C)

The velocity of muscle contraction varies inversely with the load on the muscle i.e. as the load on the muscle increases, the velocity of contraction decreases. At a given load, the velocity is maximal at the resting length and declines if the muscle is shorter or longer than this length. (Option D)

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery, supported with the image of vacoulated clusters seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig’s pearls. It is a type of after cataract.

After cataract, or secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification, is a late postoperative complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It is the most common late postoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation of left out anterior epithelial cells. Different types of after cataract include:

  • Elschnig’s pearls: The subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soap bubble like clusters along the posterior capsule.
  • Soemmering’s ring: A peripheral dense ring is formed behind the iris and is enclosed between layers of the capsule.
  • Dense membranous after-cataract: It is formed in the pupillary area impairing the vision.
  • Thin membranous after-cataract: It is thickened posterior capsule.

Treatment of after cataract is by Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy of the posterior capsule, which works on the principle of photodisruption, or surgical posterior capsulotomy. 

Option B: Irvine–Gass syndrome is cystoid macular edema (CME) that develops in post-cataract surgery patients. Though it is mostly clinically insignificant, some cases can present with blurring of vision, one to three months after surgery. In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearance and on fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) flower petal pattern can be seen. The below image depicts the flower petal pattern seen on FFA.

Option C: Post operative endophthalmitis presents as ocular pain, diminished vision and hypopyon within months to years after the surgery. Fungal endophthalmitis can rarely occur with puff ball exudates in the vitreous cavity.

Option D: UGH syndrome is where uveitis, glaucoma and hyphema occurs simultaneously. It is seen commonly with rigid anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: The cross-section of the brain of an 84-year-old man with dyslipidemia is given below, in comparison with a normal brain. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change?
questions.solution:
The given image shows narrowing of gyri and widening of sulci in a senile brain, which is suggestive of senile atrophy. It is due to a gradual decrease in blood supply as a result of atherosclerosis, known as ischemic atrophy.

The various types of pathological atrophy are:

Pathologic atrophy 
Disuse atrophy (decreased workload) Atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply) Skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
Ischemic atrophy Senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
Inadequate nutrition Severe muscle wasting in marasmus
Pressure atrophy Atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

questions.text: A 15-day-old infant had conjunctivitis, which later developed into respiratory distress and pneumonia. Chest Xray examination revealed bilateral lung infiltrates. Peripheral smear count showed 14,300/dL (N 43, L 54, E3).  Which of the following is the most likely pathogenic organism?
questions.solution:
The organism most likely to cause the mentioned infections is Chlamydia trachomatis.


Pneumonia caused by C. trachomatis can develop in 10–20% of infants born to women with active, untreated chlamydial infection. Only approximately 25% of infants with nasopharyngeal chlamydial infection develop pneumonia.

C. trachomatis pneumonia of infancy has a very characteristic presentation. 

Onset usually occurs between 1 and 3 months of age and is insidious, with a persistent cough, tachypnea, and absence of fever. Auscultation reveals rales; wheezing is uncommon.

The absence of fever and wheezing helps to distinguish C. trachomatis pneumonia from respiratory syncytial virus pneumonia.

A distinctive laboratory finding is the presence of peripheral eosinophilia (>400 cells/µL).
The most consistent finding on chest radiograph is hyperinflation accompanied by minimal interstitial or alveolar infiltrates.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presented with a 4-day history of high-grade fever and a productive cough with yellow sputum. Chest x-ray showed a consolidation in the right middle zone. According to WHO guidelines, which of the following is not an indication for hospital admission?
questions.solution:
As per the revised 2014 WHO guidelines, it is safe to treat chest indrawing pneumonia at home.

However, a child who is HIV positive and has chest indrawing will need to be referred for inpatient treatment. Only those children who have general danger signs are classified as having “severe pneumonia” and need to be referred to a higher level (hospital admission).

Danger signs:

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: Which of the following drug is recently approved by FDA to treat patients with anaplastic lymphoma kinase positive metastatic non small cell lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Lorlatinib is recently approved drug(2/11/2018) by FDA to treat patients with anaplastic lymphoma kinase positive metastatic non small cell lung cancer.

Other options:

  • Vizimpro(dacomitnib): U.S. FDA approved first line treatment with EGFR-metastatic non small cell lung cancer.
  • Lumoxiti(moxetumomab pasudotox-tdfk): FDA approved to treat hairy cell leukemia.
  • Emgality(galcanezumab): (FDA) has approved the calcitonin gene–related peptide (CGRP) antagonist, for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults.

questions.text: Hormone degradation as an important mechanism for regulating local concentrations is seen in _________.

choices.text: Degradation of  retinoic acid by  Cyp26b1 in primordial germ cells of males

questions.solution:
Hormone degradation as an important mechanism for regulating local concentrations is seen in all of the above.

11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase inactivates glucocorticoids in renal tubular cells, preventing actions through the mineralocorticoid receptor.

During development, degradation of retinoic acid by Cyp26b1 prevents the primordial germ cells in the male from entering meiosis, which occurs in the female ovary.

The thyroid hormone deiodinases convert T4 to T3 and can inactivate T3. All the three are hence examples of local hormone degradation being utilized as a method for regulation of hormone concentration locally.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to the development of T lymphocytes?
questions.solution:
PAX 5 is a B-cell transcription factor. It is not associated with the development with T lymphocytes.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man was brought to the ER by his friends after they found him lying unconscious next to an empty antifreeze bottle. Investigations were significant for the following findings. This condition predominantly affects which part of the kidney?

BUN - 60mg/dl

S. creatinine - 3.2mg/dl

S. potassium - 7mmol/L

ABG - high anion gap metabolic acidosis

Urine analysis - calcium oxalate crystals
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to ingestion of ethylene glycol. Toxins usually result in ATN by causing damage to the proximal convoluted tubules (PCTs).

Ethylene glycol poisoning produces marked ballooning and hydropic or vacuolar degeneration of PCT. Calcium oxalate crystals are often also found in tubular lumens.

Direct toxic injury to the tubules in ATI can be caused by:

  • Endogenous agents: Myoglobin, hemoglobin, monoclonal light chains, bile/bilirubin
  • Exogenous agents:  Drugs, radiocontrast dyes, heavy metals, and organic solvents

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line drug for a patient diagnosed with sarcoidosis with multiple organ involvement?
questions.solution:
The first-line drug for sarcoidosis with multiple organ involvement is prednisolone. 

Management of sarcoidosis:

  • Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression
  • Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids
  • Multisystem involvement:
    • Systemic steroids
    • Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

questions.text: Which among the following is false with respect to active phase of labor?

choices.text: The minimum rate of cervical dilatation is 1.2cm/hr in nullipara
Arrest of dilatation is cessation of dilatation for >2 hours
Arrest of descent is cessation of descent for >1 hour
Poor cervical dilatation causes prolonged active phase

questions.solution:
Poor cervical dilatation causes a prolonged latent phase.

Arrest of cervical dilatation is defined as the lack of cervical dilatation for ≥ 2 hours during the active phase of labour.

According to the Obstetric Care Consensus Committee, when cervical dilatation has reached ≥ 6 cm with ruptured membranes, and there is no cervical change despite 4 hours of adequate uterine contractions or 6 hours of inadequate contractions, a cesarean delivery is warranted.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the ER with dizziness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, pulse rate is 45/minute. Her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shown above is the second-degree atrioventricular block type 1 - Wenckebach phenomenon.

Treatment is indicated when bradycardia is accompanied by any one of the following:

  • Hypotension
  • Acutely altered mental status
  • Signs of shock
  • Ischemic chest discomfort
  • Acute heart failure

Treatment is initiated with 1 mg atropine iv which may be repeated at 3-5 minute intervals to a maximum dose of 3 mg.

Along with atropine, transcutaneous pacing is to be done.

If the bradycardia is refractory to both atropine and transcutaneous pacing, then IV infusions of dopamine (5 to 20 μg/kg/min) or epinephrine (2 to 10 μg/min) should be considered.

If the patient still isn’t responding, then transvenous pacing should be tried. If the patient is under spinal anesthesia, low-dose (0.2 mg) IV epinephrine can be given.

Epinephrine is the drug of choice for treating bradyarrhythmias in infants and children.

Related Pearl: Adult Bradycardia with Pulse Algorithm

When a patient is in bradyarrhythmia typically with a heart rate of <50 bpm the initial intervention consists of identifying and treating the underlying cause. This includes: 

  • Maintaining a patent airway and assisting breathing as necessary
  • Administering oxygen if hypoxemic
  • Attaching cardiac monitor to identify rhythm; monitor blood pressure and oximetry
  • IV access
  • 12-Lead ECG 

If the bradyarrhythmia is persisent causing hemodynamic instability, then the management is as depicted by the flowchart (based on the AHA guidelines) below:

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of norgestimate OCPs?
questions.solution:
Norgestimate is one of the 3rd generation progesterone agents. All OCPs have the disadvantage of increasing the risk of venous thrombosis. 

Third-generation progesterone agents are less androgenic and so reduce the occurrence of acne and hirsutism. They also have a lower risk of metabolic and cardiovascular disorders compared to the previous generation progesterone agents.

Benefits of combined pills:

  • Effective contraceptive
  • Useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhoea
  • Relieves dysmenorrhoea and premenstrual tension
  • Prevents anaemia by reducing the menstrual loss
  • Lower incidence of benign breast neoplasia (fibrocystic disease), functional ovarian cyst, ovarian and uterine malignancy
  • Reduced risk of PID - due to thick cervical mucus caused by progestogen, preventing the organisms from entering into the uterine cavity 
  • Reduced incidence of ectopic pregnancy - due to suppression of ovulation and decreased risk of PID
  • Protects against rheumatoid arthritis
  • Reduces the risk of anorectal cancer
  • Useful in acne, PCOD, and endometriosis

questions.text: What is the initiating event in the oncogenesis of pancreatic cancers?
questions.solution:
The activation of the K-ras 2 oncogene is the initiating event in the oncogenesis of pancreatic cancers. It is activated in more than 95% of pan­creatic cancers.

Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) develops into pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) in a sequential pathway. A number of tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes play a significant role in the pathogenesis of PDAC. They include:

  • K-ras 2
  • PDX1
  • CDKN2A/p16
  • p53
  • DPC4 (SMAD4)

questions.text: You are investigating an outbreak of diarrhea.  You find out that the etiological agent causes stacked-brick formation on hep-2 cells as shown below.  What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
The stacked-brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells is caused by enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC).

Enteroaggregative E. coli has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by aggregative adherence fimbriae (AAF). EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) is considered to be a major virulence factor for EAEC.

The given image shows the stacked-brick pattern of adherence on microscopy at 600x magnification.

questions.text: Bracket calcification on skull X-Ray is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Lipoma of the corpus callosum shows bracket calcification on skull X-ray.

Intracranial lipomas are most commonly located in the midline and are commonly associated with congenital malformations such as agenesis/dysgenesis of the corpus callosum. Pericallosal lipomas are classified into anteriorly located bulky tubulo-nodular type and posteriorly located ribbon-like curvilinear type. Imaging is the mainstay in the diagnosis of intracranial lipoma. 

The image below shows bracket calcification:

Other options:

Option A: Tuberous sclerosis shows calcification of subependymal hamartomas in the wall of the ventricles.

Option B: Sturge Weber syndrome shows tram track calcification.

Option D: Meningioma on X-ray shows calcification hyperostosis and increased vascular markings, it is usually seen in the falx.

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in ________.
questions.solution:
Cartilage is made up of type II collagen.

Type I collagen (fibrocartilage), Type II collagen (hyaline and elastic).

There are nearly 28 types of collagen. The important ones are given below with mnemonic: 

Bone, Ligament, Tendon, Aponeurosis Type I Collagen [B-ONE]
Hyaline and Elastic Cartilage  Type II Collagen [Car-Two-Lage]

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 15-day old baby to you with complaints of decreased activity and vomiting. On examination, the baby is hypotensive, has depressed fontanelles and reduced skin turgor. The image of the external genitalia of the baby is shown below. Which electrolyte abnormality can you expect to see in this baby?
questions.solution:
The image shows ambiguous genitalia. This along with signs of dehydration and hypotension suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Hyperkalemia and hyponatremia (due to mineralocorticoid deficiency) can be seen in this condition. 

These babies present at 10–14 days of age with progressive weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, dehydration, hypoglycemia, and hypotension.

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: In the image given below, identify the muscle responsible for the opening of the mouth.
questions.solution:
In the given image the structure marked B represents the lateral pterygoid muscle which is responsible for the opening of the mouth.

Lateral pterygoid:

  • Origin -
    • Upper head - Infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.
    • Lower head - Lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and the articular disc.
  • Nerve supply - Lateral pterygoid nerve which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

Other structures marked:

A - Temporalis

C - Masseter

D - Medial pterygoid

questions.text: All of the following are true about oculomotor nerve palsy except _____.
questions.solution:
Lateral and upward gaze is a sign of trochlear (4th) nerve palsy and not of oculomotor palsy. Oculomotor (3rd) nerve palsy leads to lateral and downward gaze.

3rd Cranial nerve palsy presents with

  • Ptosis(option A) due to weakness of levator palpebrae superioris muscle (LPS)
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus (6th nerve supply)  and superior oblique muscles (4th nerve supply)
  • Dilated pupil(option B), loss of light reflex(option C) and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy (involvement of Edinger Westphal parasympathetic supply)
  • Limited adduction, elevation and depression due to ipsilateral paralysis of medial rectus, inferior oblique and inferior rectus .

4th cranial nerve palsy presents with superior oblique muscle paralysis.

Clinical findings of trochlear nerve palsy include:

  • Hypertropia (elevation) in the primary position
  • Extorsion that is greatest in abduction
  • Compensatory head posture with contralateral face turn and head tilt with chin slightly depressed. This position is assumed to avoid Diplopia.
  • Limitation of depression
  • Normal abduction and elevation

The below given image depicts 4th cranial nerve palsy.

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman is not responsive to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and family history of bladder cancer. She does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, canagliflozin (Option C) is the most suitable treatment. It is an oral drug belonging to the class SGLT-2 inhibitors and causes weight loss. Although it increases the risk of urogenital infections, it has no risk of pancreatitis or bladder cancer.

Option A: Sitagliptin, a DPP-IV inhibitor, is associated with the risk of acute pancreatitis.

Option B: Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, can increase the risk of bladder cancer and can cause weight gain and congestive cardiac failure.

Option D: Liraglutide is an injectable GLP-1 receptor agonist. Pancreatitis is a serious adverse effect of this drug. Hence, it is contraindicated in individuals with a history of pancreatitis and should be permanently discontinued if pancreatitis develops.

questions.text: In a patient with asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, when will you perform parathyroidectomy?

choices.text: If bone mineral density of  > 2.5 SD above peak bone mass
In the presence of hypercalciuria but absence of nephrolithiasis
If creatinine clearance is reduced by 30%

questions.solution:
Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30% is an indication for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism.

Related Pearl: Indications for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary HPT (2013-2014 NIH Consensus Conference Guidelines)

  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal
  • Renal: 
    • Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30%
    • 24-h urine calcium >400 mg/day
    • Presence of nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis
  • Skeletal: 
    • Decreased bone mineral density (T score <-2.5)
    • Presence of vertebral fracture
  • Age <50 years

questions.text: A patient with past history of parotidectomy now presents with sweating and flushing of skin over the cheek during mastication. Which of the following nerves is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Frey's syndrome which involves the auriculotemporal nerve, marked as 2. 

Other structures marked are: 

1 - Maxillary nerve 

3 - Posterior auricular nerve 

4 - Inferior alveolar nerve

The auriculotemporal nerve is identified by its two roots which encircle the middle meningeal artery. It is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve. It gives cutaneous innervation to the tragus and the adjoining part of the auricle and carries postganglionic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland. 

Frey's syndrome is caused due to aberrant regeneration of the postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve. The nerve fibres regenerate into the nearby sweat glands. It can occur following parotid surgery, or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule. This results in sweating, warmth, and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food. Hence, Frey's syndrome is also known as gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant was brought to the pediatric OPD for a routine checkup. The child had congenital hypoparathyroidism. CT scan revealed thyroid hypoplasia and absent thymus. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal pouches will most likely cause the given features?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of congenital hypoparathyroidism and thyroid hypoplasia, absent thymus on CT scan is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. The defect is most likely to be present in the development of third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. 

Structures derived from various pharyngeal pouches (I-IV) are:

questions.text: Which of the following receptors recognize fungi?
questions.solution:
C-type lectin receptors (CLRs) detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi.

The various classes of innate immune receptors are as follows:

 Receptors Location Function
Toll-like receptors Plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles

Important TLRs and molecules recognised:

  • TLR2 - peptidoglycan of gram + bacteria, lipopolysaccharide of Leptospira
  • TLR3 - dsRNA viruses
  • TLR4Q - Chlamydia and lipopolysaccharide
NOD-like receptors Cytosol of immune cells and epithelial cells
  • Recognise substances from necrotic cells and microbial products
  • Signals via inflammasome which activates caspase and IL-1
C-type lectin receptors  Plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells
  • Detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi
RIG-like receptors Cytosol of most cell types
  • Detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of infected cells
  • Stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines
  • Recognize short bacterial peptides containing N-formyl methionyl residues and stimulate chemotaxis
Mannose receptors Plasma membrane of macrophages, immature dendritic cells, and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells
  • Detect microbial sugars (which often contain terminal mannose residues) and induce phagocytosis of the microbes

Mannose receptor is a soluble pattern-recognition receptor. All the others are surface pattern-recognition receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z?
questions.solution:
Syndrome Z is defined as a combination of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome with metabolic syndrome. LDL more than 100 mg/dL is not a criterion for the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome.

Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed based on The NCEP: ATP III Criteria. Three or more of the following must be present :

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dL or specific medication
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively, or specific medication
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥85 mmHg diastolic or specific medication
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes

questions.text: What process is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3?

choices.text: Movement of Na+ into the cell
Movement of Na+ out of the cell
Movement of K+ into the cell
Movement of K+ out of the cell

questions.solution:
The graph depicts action potential. The movement of Na+ into the cell is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3.

Once the membrane is depolarized to the threshold, local potential, the upstroke of the nerve action potential is caused by the opening of the Na+ channels. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. When the Na+ channels open, Na+ moves into the cell down its electrochemical gradient, driving the membrane potential toward the Na+ equilibrium potential.

The process responsible for repolarization is the opening of K+. The K+ permeability becomes very high and drives the membrane potential toward the K+equilibrium potential by the flow of K+ out of the cell.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the modified WHO partogram?

choices.text: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Each small square in partogram is equal to 1 hour
Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.solution:
Each small square in a modified WHO partogram is equal to 30 minutes. Each small square in a composite WHO partogram is equal to 1 hour.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanization in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency.
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 33Hz. In the above graph, we know,

  • The speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec.
  • The y-axis represents millivolts, the x-axis represents time.
  • The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • The area under the graph represents the muscle contraction.

Contraction period (latent period to maximum force of contraction) includes 3 scales = 30 mm. 

As paper speed is 1000mm/sec,

Contraction period = 30mm = (30/1000) = 30 msec. 

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1000/30 = 33Hz.

Tetanization

The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways:

  • by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ﬁber summations.
  • by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to tetanization.

When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous, this is called tetanization. 

Tetanization occurs in two ways:

  • Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated stimuli.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with a history of a cerebrovascular accident. On the second day, he becomes drowsy with minimal response. CT finding is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 53 year old patient admitted in view of a cerebrovascular accident developing neurologic deterioration (drowsy with minimal response) on the second day, and CT brain showing significant edema of MCA territory with midline shift. The next line of management is decompressive surgery.

Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days. 

Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum. 

Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration ≤ 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy. Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving ≥ one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours ≥ 80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema.

World Stroke Day is on October 29 every year. On this day, people everywhere share important information about recognizing the signs of a stroke, how to stay healthy, and ways to prevent strokes. The theme this year, as designated by WSO, is ‘Together we are #Greater Than Stroke.’ In India, the average stroke incidence rate is 145 per 1,00,000 population.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting?
questions.solution:
During fasting, there is low insulin, and hence, the activity of phosphofructokinase-1 gets inhibited.

Phosphofructokinase 1 is an enzyme of glycolysis. It is induced by insulin and a well-fed state.

Other options: 

Option A: Hormone-sensitive lipase mobilizes stored fats in a fasting state.

Option B: Glycogen phosphorylase is active in fasting state so as to produce glucose from glycogen.

Option C: Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme of gluconeogenesis. During the fasting state, the liver is flooded with fatty acids mobilized from adipose tissue. The resulting elevated hepatic acetyl CoA activates pyruvate carboxylase. Other enzymes of gluconeogenesis that are elevated in fasting include Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase, Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase, and Glucose-6-phosphatase.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male chronic smoker presents to the AIIMS OPD with fever, fatigue, yellow-colored urine, and clay-colored stools. For the past few days, he has developed an aversion to cigarette smoking. On examination icterus was present. What investigations would you advise to rule out acute viral hepatitis? Liver function test results are given below:

Total Bilirubin – 18.5
Direct Bilirubin – 7.5
SGOT – 723
SGPT – 812

choices.text: HBsAg, IgM antiHBc, AntiHDV, AntiHCV, Anti HEV

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of jaundice. The tests that should be done in this patient to rule out acute viral hepatitis include:

  • Anti-HAV
  • HBsAg
  • IgM anti-HBc
  • Anti-HCV
Condition Suspected Targetted Test Performed
Acute Hepatitis A IgM Anti-HAV
Acute Hepatitis B

HBsAg and

IgM Anti-HBc

*1 or both can be positive. A positive IgM AntiHBc with negative HBsAg is seen when HBsAg is below the detection threshold. 
Acute Hepatitis C Anti HCV

We mainly test for hepatitis A, B, and C. Tests for hepatitis D and E are not used routinely.

Hepatitis D only occurs concurrently with Hepatitis B, either as a co-infection (when it is clinically indistinguishable from HBV infection) or superimposed on chronic HBV infection. In the latter scenario, it presents as a sudden worsening of the patient’s condition. IgM anti-HDV, IgG anti-HDV, and HDV RNA assays are useful for diagnosis when hepatitis D is suspected.

Hepatitis E is not tested as the majority of patients who acquire hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection spontaneously clear the virus. Acute hepatic failure is more likely in those who are pregnant and in those who are malnourished or have preexisting liver disease. Chronic HEV has been described almost exclusively in immunocompromised hosts (e.g., organ transplantation). The diagnosis of acute HEV is typically based upon the detection of IgM antibodies to HEV. Both false positives and negatives are common with available assays and are thus, not very reliable. Thus, additional serologic testing or HEV RNA testing should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and not be useful as a screening test. [Please note the difference between anti-HBe and anti-HEV]

questions.text: Identify the site which is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area.
questions.solution:
It is a cross section of brain stem at pons.

  • A is a periaqueductal gray matter which also consists of raphe nucleus.
  • Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray matter inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways. This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiates.

Other marked structures are

B: Corticospinal tract

C: Medial lemniscus

D: Medial longitudinal fasciculus

questions.text: A patient has a right upper limb BP of 180/95 mm Hg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mm Hg. He also has an early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
A significant difference in blood pressure measured between two arms (>10 mm Hg) may be seen in Takayasu arteritis (subclavian artery disease), supravalvular aortic stenosis, aortic coarctation, and aortic dissection (all four options).

An early diastolic murmur in the right second intercostal space (aortic area) is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis (Option A), which involves the part of the aorta distal to the aortic valve, is unlikely to cause aortic regurgitation and hence the best answer.

Features  Supravalvular AS Takayasu arteritis Aortic dissection Coarctation of aorta
Aortic regurgitation Unlikely Present in 25% of cases Present in acute situations Present
BP difference between arms Present Present Present May be present

So the single best answer would be Supravalvular AS > Coarctation of the aorta.

questions.text: In a patient with influenza, there is decreased expression of MHC proteins on the surface of the virus-infected cells. Which component of the immune system acts on such cells?
questions.solution:
Natural killer cells (NK cells) act on virus-infected cells with reduced MHC expression. 

NK cells are a subtype of lymphocytes that kill damaged or infected cells. NK cells express CD16 and CD56. Their action is inhibited when MHC I is expressed on normal cells. This prevents NK Cells from killing normal cells. In the presence of a viral infection or malignancy, MHC expression of a cell is reduced. Thus, NK cells get activated and kill virus-infected/tumor cells. NK cells also secrete cytokines (IFN-γ) which activate macrophages (option B) for destruction of ingested microbes. 

Other options:

Option A: Cytotoxic T cells act when cells expressing MHC I present endogenous antigens.

Option D: Helper T cells act when cells expressing MHC II (antigen-presenting cells) present exogenous antigens.

questions.text: An AIDS patient on treatment with  AZT, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole, and cotrimoxazole, develops breast hypertrophy, central adiposity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and nephrolithiasis. Which of the following drugs could have caused these?
questions.solution:
Indinavir, a protease inhibitor, is the most likely cause for these adverse effects.

Patients being treated with protease inhibitors (e.g., indinavir) develop a syndrome involving the derangement of lipid metabolism. This causes changes in body fat distribution. Type 2 diabetes mellitus has also been reported. This is called HIV/HAART-associated lipodystrophy.

Indinavir can also precipitate in the urinary tract, causing nephrolithiasis, unless the patient is maintained in a high state of hydration.

Indinavir binds to the site of HIV-1 protease activity and inhibits cleavage of viral gag-pol polyprotein precursors into individual functional proteins required for infectious HIV. This results in the formation of immature, non-infectious viral particles.

Option A: Azidothymidine or zidovudine, is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Chronic zidovudine administration has been associated with nail hyperpigmentation. 

Option C: Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that inhibits fungal ergosterol synthesis. Its adverse effects include liver dysfunction and testosterone synthesis inhibition leading to gynecomastia. 

Option D: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It is one of the least toxic antiretroviral drugs. Neutropenia, headache, and nausea have been reported at higher-than-recommended doses.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent postpartum hemorrhage?

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.solution:
As per the latest guidelines, uterine massage is no longer a core component of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) that is performed for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

Uterine massage or fundal massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin (core component of AMTSL). Hence, it is now an optional component of AMTSL that is done in patients with uterine atony as a part of the management of PPH.

AMTSL is recommended by the WHO to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Uterotonics are the most important components in AMTSL to do so.

The currently recommended components of AMTSL are as follows:

1. Injecting uterotonics within 1 minute of delivery of the baby or immediately after delivery of the anterior shoulder
  • Most important step
  • Oxytocin 10 IU im/iv infusion is the preferred uterotonic.

(Not recommended by WHO- carboprost)

 
2 Delayed cord clamping
  • Done within 1-3 mins of delivery
  • 80 ml of additional blood goes to the fetus
  • Prevents fetal anemia
3 Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction: Modified Brandt Andrews technique
  • The uterus is pushed upwards and backward
  • The traction of cord is downwards and forwards
4 Intermittent assessment of uterine tone Done every 15 mins for 2 hours

Note: In the event that uterine atony is diagnosed during the assessment of uterine tone, uterine massage can be performed to control PPH.

questions.text: A patient has chronic cough with occasional blood in the sputum. He has a history of significant weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following media cannot be used to culture the organism causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough and hemoptysis with a concurrent history of significant weight loss and night sweats most likely has tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. McLeod's medium is not used to culture M. tuberculosis. It is a selective medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis include:

  • Solid- Loeffler's medium is a serum-containing solid medium used for the culture of M. tuberculosis. Other solid media used include Lowenstein- Jensen medium, Dorset medium, Tarshis medium, and Pawlowsky's medium.
  • Liquid- Middlebrook’s media are used for the preparation of antigens and vaccines and in sensitivity testing.  Other examples of liquid mycobacterial culture media include Dubos' medium, Sula's medium and Sauton's medium.
  • Automated culture methods: 
    • BACTEC 460- uses radioisotopes for detection
    • BacT alert- colorimetric method of detection
    • BACTEC MGIT- fluorometric detection method.

questions.text: Which of the following is a combined immunodeficiency disorder associated with both B-cell and T-cell defects?
questions.solution:
Louis–Bar syndrome or ataxia-telangiectasia is a combined immunodeficiency disorder. 

Ataxia-telangiectasia is a syndrome complex that comprises neurologic, immunologic, endocrinologic, and cutaneous disorders. The gene involved in this condition is the mutation in the ATM gene mapped to the long arm of chromosome 11(11q22-23). The mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive. There is defective DNA repair and increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation. 

Clinical features:

  • Progressive cerebellar ataxia
  • Oculocutaneous telangiectasias 
  • Chronic sinopulmonary disease
  • High incidence of malignancy - adenocarcinomas and lymphoreticular tumors (lymphoma, leukemia, and Hodgkin's disease)
  • Humoral and cellular immunodeficiency
  • Ovarian dysgenesis and chromosomal abnormalities
  • Hypoplastic thymus
  • Ataxia and chorioathetoid movements start in infancy. 

The onset of telangiectasia is around 3 to 6 years and involves the face, conjunctiva and other parts of the body. By 12 years of age, affected children are usually confined to wheelchairs due to progressive ataxia. 

Death occurs due to sinopulmonary infection in early life or due to malignancy in the second or third decade. They lack IgA and IgE. Cell-mediated immunity is also defective. 

The image below shows ocular telangiectasia in a patient with A-T.

Other options: 

Option B: DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder associated with T-cell deficiency.

Options C and D: Chediak-Higashi syndrome and tuftsin deficiency are disorders of phagocytosis.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Name  the instrument given below is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Czerny's retractor. Czerny’s Retractor is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision.

Option A: Morris Retractor is a big retractor which is useful for giving a maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Option C: Double hook Retractor is used:

  • To retract skin flap for excision of sebaceous cyst.
  • During venesection for retraction of skin.
  • During tracheostomy for retraction of skin and thyroid isthmus.

Option D: Deaver’s Retractor is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors
